Award.AwardTitle: Implementation Project: Student-Centered Active Learning and Assessment Reform (SCALAR)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Implementation Project entitled: Student-Centered Active Learning and Assessment Reform (SCALAR) at Florida A&M University (FAMU) will implement a series of innovative curricular and co-curricular initiatives that will ultimately position the university as a national leader in STEM education. The project involves a complete restructuring of the undergraduate course curricula and instructional approaches in the areas of mathematics, chemistry, physics, biology, and computer science. All of the program areas are housed in a newly created College of Science and Technology, which will facilitate the seamless and focused implementation of the project activities. Specific program components include: the redesign of course curricula to include a specific instructional focus on using active learning strategies to teach STEM concepts; a comprehensive assessment strategy that will be integrated into the course design and will be continuously used to modify the instructional strategy in order to optimize student learning; the creation of a faculty development program to increase faculty use of pedagogical best practices; the development of an online seminar series, which will be presented by leading scientists from institutions across the country; and the development of a centralized STEM tutorial center.

Over 5000 undergraduate students at FAMU, where the enrollment is approximately 90% African-American, will be impacted by this project. The broader impact will result from documentation of how a student-centered learning environment that is integrated into the STEM curriculum will be created, and from the wide dissemination of the documentation. The FAMU SCALAR project will thus serve as a model for the sustainable transformation of the undergraduate STEM curriculum to incorporate evidence-based best-practices in STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SCALAR Project Outcomes Report

Florida A&M University (FAMU) in Tallahassee, FL received an NSF Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) grant entitled “Student-Centered Active Learning and Assessment Reform (SCALAR).” The project was funded for four years from Aug 2013 through July 2017. The overarching goal of SCALAR was to significantly enhance the overall quality of the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) educational experience at FAMU by revamping the institutional approach for educating STEM students in lower-division courses offered by the recently established College of Science and Technology. The SCALAR project included a set of interrelated activities to enhance: a) faculty instruction and assessment of student learning; b) the classroom learning environment via increased use of active-learning classroom spaces; c) the STEM co-curricular experience; d) student professional development; and e) STEM outreach.  The SCALAR project introduced several new initiatives to the university and has had a significant impact on student success, student learning, and the overall environment that facilitates student learning in STEM disciplines at FAMU.

Active learning is a proven practical instructional approach to improve student success and increase engagement in STEM courses. To increase the use of active learning among faculty, the STEM Faculty Development program was implemented under the SCALAR project.  Faculty members participated in the program during the summers to develop their abilities to teach in Active Learning environments. Furthermore, the university made investments by creating three Student-Centered Active Learning for Undergraduate Programs (SCALE-UP) classrooms. The SCALAR project provided the training of the faculty on best practices when using the classrooms.  Over the span of the project, pass rates (A, B, C grades) in several of the target gatekeeper courses (General Chemistry, College Algebra, and General Physics) have shown significant increases.  As a result of these improvements, an additional 515 passing grades were earned in 2015-16. Since the start of the project, at least 50% of the college’s faculty report that they regularly use active learning strategies in their teaching.  Moreover, at least 25-course sections are taught in the Active Learning Classrooms each year. 

The Science Seminar series was created to help with STEM student professional development, as well as improve student persistence in the STEM major.  During each year, several speakers were brought in to speak to the students about tackling the challenges of college and determining a career path. Surveys administered to student participants in the STEM Student Seminars Series indicate that 81% said their interest in STEM careers increased and 78% said their interest in graduate school has increased.

The SCALAR project established STEM Day: an annual outreach event for K-12 school students to increase STEM awareness and interest in pursuing STEM careers. Through participation in hands-on learning activities, student participants have the opportunity to explore the scientific process and gain valuable problem-solving experiences in STEM disciplines. Moreover, parents have a program to help develop/support their child's interest in STEM careers.  Four STEM Days have been held (one per year), and over 750 students and 150 parents have participated to date.  This activity has grown to become the Universities' signature STEM outreach event. The University has committed to continuing this effort.

To our knowledge, SCALAR is the first successful wide-scale implementation of the SCALE-UP Active Learning model in an HBCU environment. The results of the project demonstrate how this instructional best practice can be implemented efficiently in a sustainable way at minority-serving institutions.  Moreover, the project has been shown to be a mechanism for increasing success rates of minority students enrolled in STEM gateway courses. The University is committed to the sustainability of these efforts to improve student performance.
